post_text: Congratulations, Hedgesville High School! What an accomplishment!
shared_text:
CFWV
August 18 at 3:00 PM ·

Congratulations to Hedgesville High School! They are the first school in West Virginia to receive the American College Application Campaign’s School of Excellence Award. They were recognized due to their strong commitment to helping students complete their college applications and continue their education during West Virginia’s College Application and Exploration Week held last November. The American College Application Campaign (ACAC) works to increase the number of first-generation college students and students from low-income families pursuing a college degree or other form of higher education after graduation. Nearly 7,300 high schools hosted College Application Campaign events nationwide in coordination with the ACAC last year. Read more about this great honor at http://www.cfwvconnect.com/west-virginia-high-school-receives-american-college-application-campaigns-school-of-excellence-award/.

An encouraging note from Talkline with Hoppy Kercheval:

Applications are being accepted from students and young adults, ages 14-21 years, who reside in Boone, Cabell, Kanawha, Lincoln, Logan, Mingo, and Putnam counties for the newly created West Virginia Human Rights Commission (HRC) Youth Ambassador Program. The program is an initiative of HRC Director Dr. Ronald L. Jones.

“The HRC Youth Ambassador Program is a grassroots initiative designed to create an environment of inclusion and diversity while building youth leadership,” said Dr. Jones. “The goal of this program is to teach our youth about human rights and equip them with the tools necessary to promote tolerance and to appropriately intercede when human rights are violated.”

Grants will be available to these Youth Ambassadors to promote human rights in their schools and communities.

The HRC Youth Ambassador training will be held March 26, 2020, at West Virginia State University. To apply, contact James Westbrook: James.R.Westbrook@wv.gov or (304) 558-2616.

Representatives from the West Virginia Department of Education and Marshall University unveiled the #ReClaimWV Initiative, the West Virginia Department of Education's comprehensive program designed to support educators, school personnel, families and students affected by the substance misuse crisis in West Virginia.

The West Virginia Department of Education and Marshall University highlighted the work of the West Virginia Behavior/Mental Health Technical Assistance Center (TAC). Housed within the Marshall University Autism Training Center, the TAC was created by the Department to provide statewide support to the education community to address the mental health, behavior, and social-emotional needs of students and educators. The TAC provides both in-depth training and technical assistance to educators statewide. An easy-to-use online request form ensures a timely response regardless of the school’s location.

Visit wvde.us/reclaimwv to learn more.
